title: 104_hr3752
content: The Act titled "American Land Sovereignty Protection Act of 1996" is established for the purpose of protecting American land sovereignty. The Act "American Land Sovereignty Protection Act of 1996" emphasizes Congress's authority over US lands and the need for laws to implement international land designations like the Biosphere Reserve Program. The United States National Man and Biosphere Committee, without congressional authorization, may impact nearby non-Federal lands. State sovereignty and private property rights are crucial, and US actions in designating lands under international agreements can conflict with congressional responsibilities and State capabilities. The Act aims to reaffirm Congress's authority over international agreements concerning US lands, protect State powers, and ensure no loss of individual rights due to Federal actions under such agreements. Federal actions designating lands pursuant to international agreements for imposing restrictions on land use, protecting private property interests, and providing a process for the US to designate lands under international agreements. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF CONGRESSIONAL ROLE IN WORLD HERITAGE SITE LISTING. Section 401 of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 is amended to restrict the Secretary of the Interior from nominating US lands for the World Heritage List without specific authorization from a law enacted after 1996. The Land Sovereignty Protection Act of 1996 requires the Secretary of the Interior to seek authorization from Congress before nominating US properties for the World Heritage List. The Secretary must also object to including any US property on the World Heritage in Danger list without proper justification. Additionally, an annual report on each World Heritage Site in the US must be submitted to the Chairman. The Land Sovereignty Protection Act of 1996 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to obtain Congress' approval before nominating US properties for the World Heritage List. The Secretary must also object to listing any US property on the World Heritage in Danger list without valid justification. An annual report on each US World Heritage Site must be submitted to the relevant committees, detailing expenses, staffing, contributions from non-governmental organizations, and complaints received by the Secretary. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION AND TERMINATION OF UNITED NATIONS BIOSPHERE RESERVES. Title IV of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 prohibits Federal officials from nominating any lands in the United States for designation as a Biosphere Reserve under the Man and Biosphere Program of UNESCO. Any such designation must be authorized by a law enacted after the American Land Sovereignty Protection Act of 1996 and before December 31, 1999. The Biosphere Reserve must consist of lands owned by the United States and have a management plan that does not restrict adjacent non-Federal property. The Secretary of State must submit an annual report on each reserve, detailing expenses, federal hours spent on management, and any involvement of non-governmental entities. The annual report on each Biosphere Reserve must include a list of nongovernmental organizations involved in management and a summary of complaints received by the Secretary. SEC. 5. INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS IN GENERAL. Title IV of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 is amended to require specific authorization by law for any Federal official to nominate, classify, or designate lands owned by the United States for special use under international agreements. The President can propose legislation for such nominations. State or local government-owned lands also require specific authorization by state law for international agreements to have any effect. The section specifies that any nomination, classification, or designation of privately owned lands under international agreements requires written consent from the landowner. Exceptions include sites nominated under specific conventions and agreements established under certain acts. The term 'international agreement' encompasses treaties, compacts, executive agreements, conventions, or bilateral agreements. The term 'international agreement' includes treaties, compacts, executive agreements, conventions, or bilateral agreements between the US and foreign entities for conserving the environment. SEC. 6. CLERICAL AMENDMENT. Amends Section 401(b) of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 by changing "Committee on Natural Resources" to "Committee on Resources".
